I found it quite amusing as some reviews claimed this CD's the same old boring thing. Well, this is what you'd expect from her when you bought the CD right? I mean you could always get the best selling Now That's What I Call Music series of CDs if variety is what you desire. But being you purchased this CD, I assume you have a heart for Enya's style of music. I would be disappointed if Enya wastes her beautiful vocal on a pop single. Wouldn't you?
B000000W5N|5.0|STICKY FINGERS, like AFTERMATH before it, marks another major turning point for the Stones. And I'm not just talking about the move to their own record label. LET IT BLEED was the last Stones album Brian Jones played on. I doubt that anyone fully realized how much he would be missed. Jones gave the Stones a pop sensibility comparable to what McCartney gave to the Beatles. He also had a versatility that enabled him to play just about any instrument that came to hand and he had a flair for arranging music. His touch is especially notable in Stones albums from AFTERMATH through LET IT BLEED. But, with STICKY FINGERS, the Stones began to eschew simple acoustic songs like &quot;Lady Jane&quot; and &quot;Backstreet Girl&quot;, moving instead toward a denser, more layered sound like what you hear on &quot;Sway&quot; and &quot;Wild Horses&quot;.<br />STICKY FINGERS is a great album, but I must confess that it has never been one of my favorites. For me, it just doesn't have the accessibility or the listenability of earlier efforts like AFTERMATH, BEGGARS BANQUET or LET IT BLEED. Warm, homey tunes like &quot;Dear Doctor&quot;, &quot;Prodigal Son&quot;, &quot;Factory Girl&quot; and &quot;Monkey Man&quot; give way here to the stark perfection of &quot;Sister Morphine&quot; and the somewhat lugubrious &quot;Sway&quot;.<br />The album begins with one of the Stones best rockers. &quot;Brown Sugar&quot; has a great guitar riff, and the dynamite rhythm guitar drives this cut from beginning to end. &quot;Sway&quot; and &quot;Wild Horses&quot; are fine songs, but with a slow tempo and &quot;heavy&quot;, layered, ponderous quality, that have kept them from being real favorites of mine. Then comes &quot;Can't You Hear Me Knocking&quot;, which just cooks for about two and a half minutes before suddenly morphing into the most un-Stones-like jazz instrumental imaginable. Another verse, another chorus, and this would have been a great rock song. As it is, it's an enigma. &quot;You Gotta Move&quot; is a throwback to the band's early, R&amp;B days. &quot;Bitch&quot; is a nice rocker. &quot;I Got The Blues&quot; is another blues/R&amp;B throwback. Then there's the cold &quot;Sister Morphine&quot;. A brilliant piece, but not one you pop in to sing along with while driving down the freeway. Catchy rock-and-roll gives way to &quot;art&quot;. Jagger gives the vocal on &quot;Dead Flowers&quot; a loopy sound, as though he's making fun of himself. The album closes with &quot;Moonlight Mile&quot;, another pretty tune but slow and burdened with layers of orchestration.<br />STICKY FINGERS is one of the great rock albums. A classic. Whenever I actually sit down and listen to it, I always enjoy it. And I'm always impressed by it. Usually, though, when I get it out, I just listen to &quot;Brown Sugar&quot; and then put it away. Is it possible for something to be too good? I don't know, but if it is, this album would be my candidate for the honor. Still, if you have any interest in rock music or in the Stones at all, you gotta have this. It's one of the essentials of the genre. You'll find stuff on it to like. I always do. Highly recommended.e&quot; is a throwback to the band's early, R&amp;B days. &quot;Bitch&quot; is a nice rocker. &quot;I Got The Blues&quot; is another blues/R&amp;B throwback. Then there's the cold &quot;Sister Morphine&quot;. A brilliant piece, but not one you pop in to sing along with while driving down the freeway. Catchy rock-and-roll gives way to &quot;art&quot;. Jagger gives the vocal on &quot;Dead Flowers&quot; a loopy sound, as though he's making fun of himself. The album closes with &quot;Moonlight Mile&quot;, another pretty tune but slow and burdened with layers of orchestration.<br />STICKY FINGERS is one of the great rock albums. A classic. Whenever I actually sit down and listen to it, I always enjoy it. And I'm always impressed by it. Usually, though, when I get it out, I just listen to &quot;Brown Sugar&quot; and then put it away. Is it possible for something to be too good? I don't know, but if it is, this album would be my candidate for the honor. Still, if you have any interest in rock music or in the Stones at all, you gotta have this. It's one of the essentials of the genre. You'll find stuff on it to like. I always do. Highly recommended.
0486407217|5.0|Have you ever wondered how they made those lovely turn-of-the-century gowns?  This book tells you how they did it! A reprint of a 1905 Butterick sewing book, it is intended for readers who aready know how to sew, as no beginning techniques are included.  Full of vintage photographs and detailed instructions, this book gives step by step procedures for many tailoring techniques which we rarely see on anything but designer wear.  These techniques can be applied by any seamstress to produce a more fitted and tailored look to their fashions. Definately worth owning for any costumer or fashion designer looking for a more romantic and tailored look in their fashions.

B000002MJC|5.0|I started out not being impressed with this album on the first listen because it seemed such a departure from their usual sound and had much more of a \\"rock\\" sound. Don't let this deter you! The rock is seamlessly and quietly blended in so that it meshes perfectly with signature DM style (you can breathe easy, trust me). I ended up LOVING this album and cannot get it out of my head. The best songs are \\"Rush,\\" a sexually charged romp that bites your heart and burns angry tears of passion-and also, \\"One Caress\\"  which is the most beautiful sweet, delicate, sad melody that just glitters from the whole album. It is the one song that will pierce your mind and soul with deliciously haunting cellos, strings and other orchestral manoeuvres in the dark. You will notice that every song on this album starts out slow and lonely, then violently EXPLODES into melody.<br />SOFAD is sheer brilliance. The overall vibe is of melancholia (of course) only more aggressive, stabbed with guitar stylings while still being DM with its electro-synth beats and hooks which are signature of synthpop. However, if you're not familiar with DM, don't get this album right away. It's just not the proper segueway into appreciating them fully. Listen to their earlier works and then get this one---as a satisfying piece de resistance.

0876852630|5.0|This is the third book of Bukowski's that i have read (the first two were &quot;Post Office&quot; and &quot;Hollywood&quot;) and thus far it is my favorite. <br />This book is composed of a series of short passages, 87 total. This book is mostly about Henry Chinaski (meaning, for the most part, Charles Bukowski) drinking, having sex with women who drink, and moving from job to job. I dont know how many jobs Chinaski has in this book, but he often holds them only long enough for a single one-page section. <br />If there is any unity in terms of story and plot in this book, it is found in the women, such as Jan and Laura, who manage to stay in Chinaski's life for a few jobs; the women serve to string together the sections. <br />More significant than any plot are the various interwoven themes that Bukowski deals with, such as futility, solitary existence, and death (all themes that might lead us to link Bukowski with existentialist philosophy). These ideas (among others) are all related, and also related to the ways in which they are expressed, namely, through alcohol, cheap sex, disgust towards humanity, and peacefulness in the strangest situations-- and of course, Henry Chinaski's inability to hold a job or even have any desire to do so. On one hand, this book is a quick and light read; on the other hand, a close read that keeps in mind the interplay between the different themes involved truly exposes the genius of Bukowski. <br />Overall, this is a book that for the most part ends where it begins (it begins with Chinaki arriving in New Orleans and &quot;looking for the poor section&quot; and ends in a go-go bar, with Chinaski holding his last 38 cents), but this circularity, i find, is intimate to the theme of futility: why go anywhere? why do anything? As Bukowski writes in the movie &quot;Barfly&quot;, &quot;Who made up this rule that everybody has to 'be somebody'?&quot; Chinaski doesn't refuse to &quot;be somebody&quot; (remember, he has a great will to write),but he refuses to do it in terms set by other people; he refuses to define himself in terms of occupation, and other surface illusions--as to be somebody in such a way, he finds, is far too confining. On a side note, it seems as if Bukowski lifted a lot of material from this book when writing the script for &quot;Barfly,&quot; as Laura becomes Wanda in the film and both the book and the film have Wilbur, among other similarities. Overall, this is a fine book that is both an enjoyable read and constantly impresses the reader with clever insights into what we often take as ordinary.
B00000J9HE|5.0|This is a 2 CD set which can be recommended to those who do not normally react well to Karajan's music making.  His interpretations are legendary, and the recordings are excellent, bearing in mind they are 35 years old.<br />The Fifth especially (recorded for the 100th anniversary of the composer's birth) is one of the recorded classics, and the recordings of the other works are hardly inferior.<br />Sibelius himself, on hearing Karajan's 1950s Philharmonia Orchestra mono recordings of his music, said 'Karajan is the only conductor who knows what I meant', and when one listens to this set, one can hear why.<br />If you want these works on CD, do not hesitate.

B000002JS8|5.0|Highway to Hell is not only a classic album but it's one of the greatest of all time. This is AC/DC's last album with original singer Bon Scott before his death. The band is in top form on this album, the rhythm section of Phil Rudd and Cliff Williams is very solid, and rhythm guitarist Malcolm Young plays the perfect rhythm parts to compliment his bother Angus' amazing leads. The songs on Highway to Hell are pure heavy metal, so if you don't like metal, don't bother even looking for this cd. All of the songs stick to the same format as all of AC/DC's music has for the last 27 years, straightforward upbeat metal. This album features one of AC/DC's most well known songs, Highway to Hell. There are also many fan favorites on this album such as Girls Got Rhythm, Shot Down in Flames, Night Prowler, and my personal favorite off this album, If You Want Blood (You've Got It). The less well know songs such as Walk All Over You, Get It Hot, and Touch Too Much are also great. This is an excellent album reccommended to anyone.

B00004LN16|5.0|Stiff Upper Lip is AC/DC's best album in a long time. While all of their other albums throughout the 80's and 90's have been good Stiff Upper Lip blows them all away. AC/DC manages to start 2000 on a high note with one of the best albums of the year. Singer Brian Johnson's voice seems to have gotten more powerful since the Ballbreaker album, just when everyone was doubting him he comes back and surprises everyone. As far as the band what else can be said, they've been making the same style of music for almost 30 years and they still sound great. This is Phil Rudd's second album back with the band, and he and bassist Cliff Williams prove that they are one of the greatest rhythm sections of all time, and of course you can't forget rhythm guitarist Malcolm Young, he is one of the most underrated rhythm players ever. Then of course there's lead guitarist Angus Young, what else can be said about him, besides the fact that he's one of the greatest guitarists of our time, with his simple blues based riffs and solos he's gained respect from many other musicians for playing under his ability. It is also the reason why he's also very underrated, as the whole band is. Stiff Upper Lip was produced by George Young, brother of Angus and Malcolm, who produced their early albums. You can expect from this album what you'd expect from any other AC/DC album. It's very much blues rock, so if you didn't like them before the odds are that this album won't do it for you. There are many upbeat rockers on this album such as the title track, Safe in New York City, Can't Stop Rock and Roll, Satellite Blues, Damned, Give It Up and All Screwed Up. There are also some laid back songs that are very bluesy such as Meltdown, House of Jazz, Can't Stand Still, and Come And Get It. Stiff Upper Lip is a great album, the best AC/DC has put out in years, but like I said before if you don't already like AC/DC this album probably won't change your mind, but if you do like them definately get this one.

B00005AFVR|4.0|Having caught Bruce &amp; the E Street Band on their reunion tour, this live CD captures the excitement and sheer artistry of this veteran, seasoned unit.  As a lifelong fan, one who has been a fan since '73, I have to say that after all this time, Bruce and the guys are tighter than ever.  The sound quality on the CD is superb; the mix between Bruce's singing and the band's musicianship is nothing short of excellent. Max's drumming is superhuman; the 3 guitar attack of Bruce, Steve &amp; Nils never misses it's mark.  And how about Steve himself?  That was a great move, bringing him back in the fold. The performance: how can you argue?  If you caught the HBO concert special, you can just begin to realize just how damn good these guys are in concert.  There is nobody better; not today, not back in 1978 when they were arguably at their all-time peak.  Sound quality is probably the best of any of Bruce's live efforts to date.  This collection does the &quot;Live '75-'85&quot; collection one better; as for the &quot;MTV Plugged&quot;....let's not go there, OK? Those of us who are true fans know that the '92-'93 Tour (also known as the Lost in the Desert years) was a joke, save for the performance of &quot;If I Should Fall Behind&quot; from that disc.  Otherwise, that one just plain sucked.  Just listen to the E Street Band's take on the new CD of &quot;Atlantic City&quot; and you realize 2 things: first, the MTV Plugged version is weak, and second this song should have been electrified all along.<br />So why do I give only 4 stars instead of 5? Because Bruce could have done this one even better had he not dropped in &quot;Born to Run&quot; at the last minute.  Did he really need to put this song out live for a third time? NO.  I also question his putting out for the second time a live version of &quot;Tenth Avenue Freeze-Out&quot;  Yes it was a show-stopper, but 16 minutes worth is time wasted.  He could have used the opportunity to put out a live version of &quot;The Promise&quot; or &quot;The E Street Shuffle&quot; from the 2 NYC shows.  &quot;The Ties that Bind&quot; or something from another night on the stand would have worked also: &quot;Trapped&quot; &quot;Factory&quot;  &quot;Back in your Arms&quot;; the possibilities could have been endless.  So to that end, I'm a little.....and I emphasize A LITTLE...disappointed.  But, all in all, this is a killer collection.  The performances of &quot;Atlantic City&quot; &quot;Mansion...&quot; &quot;Youngstown&quot; &quot;Murder Inc&quot; and &quot;Badlands&quot; are as riveting as you'll ever hear on CD.  Disc 2 highlights are a dead-on &quot;Lost in the Flood&quot; (finally!) and a superb acoustic version of &quot;BITUSA&quot;.<br />Bruce played it smart here in the sense that he gave his public 2 new songs, the excellent &quot;American Skin&quot; and the uplifting &quot;Land of Hope &amp; Dreams&quot;.  These guys have alot of steam left in them.  This disc proves it.  I just wish he'd listen to what the fans want more.  A couple of different tunes, and this would be 5 star all the way.<br />A minor flaw on an otherwise excellent collection.  The E street Band is back!  Give it a listen and hear what real rock'n'roll is about.

If that survey was conducted in 1975, I would not object to Clapton being placed in the top five, but in the year 2000, come on! If you want to hear examples of Clapton's work when he truly was a great guitarist, buy Bluesbreakers with Eric Clapton, when he was the lead guitarist with legendary Brit bluesman John Mayall.  Additionally, buy all of Cream's albums.  <br />To summarize, a strong album displaying Clapton's talent at writing popular songs that received much radio airtime.  This is not the cd for music fans looking for examples of the man's [former] brilliance on the guitar.

B000051VWW|3.0|I have been a Sade fan since her first album came out, have all of her other cd's and have listened to several of them probably two hundred times a piece.  After her long hiatus, I expected Sade to have stored up some really special melodies for this cd.  Well, it appears that she spent her long period away from the musical spotlight focusing more on her family than on being a songwriter.  I can't criticize that at all in a general sense, but the result is that this cd is a couple notches below that of her other albums.<br />Per the VH-1 Sade special, I now understand that &quot;Lovers Rock&quot; is actually a bit of a double entendre, as it is a style of slower, more sensual music that has African and Caribbean influences and is a distant, more refined cousin of reggae.  I have never heard of this style of music before (although I have been heavily intersted in music of all sorts for the past two decades)and I doubt that this cd will promote that style to any further popularity.<br />In her prior works, Sade's incredible voice just entrances the listener, but the rythm of her songs is equally effective, reaching out with an invisible, velvet-covered gauntlet to impart a gentle sway in the listener's shoulders.  No portion of this album has that effect.  As others have stated, this cd has a slower, much less upbeat sound than her prior works, and less originality; many of the songs sound so similar that if a one were to have this playing in the background while focused on some task, one might not even notice the transitions between songs.  <br />If another artist sang these same songs, it would probably deserve a 1 star rating.  Sade still has the smoothest, most sensual voice of any current singer.  However, her voice is just not enough to carry her beyond mediocrity on this cd.  There seems to be a recent trend of artists focusing (sometimes quite arrogantly) so much on their voices that they disregard having memorable tunes or instrumental accompanyment to theirsongs (e.g. Sarah McLaughlin, Sting)and it seems that Sade has taken a few steps down this road.  There is also a recent trend for groups to market lousy material that pales in comparison to their earlier works and a further trend for many longtime fans of the group to lap it up out of thoughtless devotion to their idols, without spending a second of time attempting to make an intelligent, discriminating evaluation of the new music's quality (e.g. groups ranging from U2 to Jimmy Buffet to Sarah McLaughlin).  These trends are unfortunate, and it seems that Sade and the 5 star-reviewing fans of this album have acquiesced to them.<br />This cd is very comparable to U-2's All That You Can't Leave Behind, but without the single great song &quot;Beautiful Day.&quot;  If you loved that album and are a Sade fan, you will likely love this album also.  If you have a bit more discriminating taste and found U-2's latest cd to be bland, you will likely find this cd to be bland and would rate it at the bottom of the list for Sade's music.

0385501005|5.0|Yes, here it is, another book about a single Londoner, unlucky in love and with jobs.. but this time around, our heroine is actually a hero - wow. And I must admit, that while I enjoy the Bridge Jones books and their clones, this was a welcome break from that formula and opened up a whole new world by showing things from the male perspective.<br />Instead of the perfect boyfriend, this time around there's a perfect girlfriend our hero has mucked things up with - and the central theme ... can Duffy commit or not? Despite the very typical premise of a commitment-phobe male, Mr. Commitment is not a typical book - it's extremely well-written, humorous, enjoyable and quite believable. As Duffy reaches his decision, you realize that you've pretty much watched him get there, seen why he did it, watched him bond the way guys do and everything falls into place without being contrived or too shmarmy (of course there is some shmarm, as it's also basically a romance). And it didn't feel as though someone had taken the same old plot and simply switched genders - throughout it felt as though things were being told from a male perspective.<br />I definitely enjoyed this book both more than I expected and more than I've liked others in a similar vein. There are great characters, a good story, humor, drama (of the funny sort) and a whole new lens through which to view things. I think this book has a lot to offer to anyone, whether or not you like the genre. I came away very impressed and surprised by how much I liked it and how highly I recommend it.

0792833201|5.0|POLTERGEIST: (noun)-meaning noisy ghosts. See movie for details.<br />I saw this movie for the first time back when it was released in 1982. I was twelve years old at the time, and found it genuinely frightening.  Now that I'm older and have seen it many times, it doesn't scare me so much anymore, but it still delivers.  A collaboration between Steven Spielberg (of such films as....well you know!) and Tobe Hooper (director of The Texas Chain Saw Massacre). POLTERGEIST is the only ghost story that I have ever seen that delivers chills, state-of-the-art special effects, and unforgettable (and very believable) performances by the entire cast, yet remains in a class all its own simply because it laces these elements with both humor and warmth.<br />After living in their brand new house for the last five years, the very close Freeling family starts to notice strange happenings every now and then. Particularly observant is 5-year old Carol Anne (Heather O'Rourke as an absolute doll).  At first the ghostly pranks are a little exciting to the family, but soon they realize the ghosts are not simply just playing around, but mean real business.  The POLTERGEIST swings into full force, making it's intentions clear, pulling the family into a living nightmare from which they may not escape.<br />This DVD edition doesn't really offer many extras, but the picture is the best that I've ever seen (the televised versions that we saw for years were very grainy, even blurred).  An interesting observation that I made was that the theatrical trailer actually shows some extended sequences/dialogue that are not in the film (?).  Maybe we'll be treated to a special edition somewhere down the line.  Followed in 1986 by the sequel POLTERGEIST II: The Other Side, which would've been slightly better had Hooper or Speilberg been involved.

0800177177|4.0|Keanu Reeve's excrable performance amid an otherwise excellent cast threatens to take the whole film down with it. Only Copolla's rock-steady vision, combined with Oldman's astonishing performance as the man/beast Dracula preserve the glory of this enduring myth. Part tribute, part remake, Copolla eschews modern special effects and deliberately uses only effects possible in Todd Browning's day. A clever prologue and epilogue leave the original novel fairly intact while adding immensely to the story's meaning and depth.  Embued with this extra dimension, Drac rises from the level of mere spooky monster to that of classic tragic figure.  Coppola also manages to flesh out Stoker's wooden victorians with some entertaining human touches.  Why not five whole stars?  Reeve's performance will make you squirm; you actually feel embarrassed for him.

0618001905|5.0|This book should be required reading for world history education.  Adam Hochschild has performed a service to humanity by presenting the gruesome facts about the extermination of a people through greed, corruption and ritual murder in such a way as to present a fair report championing the rights of the oppressed, while explaining the motivations of the oppressors within the beliefs of the times.   This book was impossible not to finish, mainly because to deny the enormity of the slaughter and the secrets exposed felt like a personal rejection of the innocents.  Months later I'm still thinking about it.  What is so soulshattering is that the Congo again, starting in 1959, has experienced yet another unbelievable decimation of its population through (admittedly well-intentioned) polio vaccination and misguided food sources resulting in the crossover of SIV to AIDS.  Who is writing their story today?

If there's one thing they've shown us throughout their association with the Highlander &quot;franchise&quot;, it's that they'll stoop to new lows to milk their cash cow, with no regard to continuity whatsoever.  Supporters take the stance that, for their to be any sequels, the end of the original film must be ignored.  This isn't so: a character who's 450 years old has plenty of history to explore, and there could've been any number of stories to tell in that time frame.  As for the character of Duncan, and the television series, all they really had to do was set the show sometime before 1985, when the first film took place.  Sure, it would've been a little more expensive, but it would've been worth it, and would've shown more respect to the source material.<br />Now that that's said, I must say that despite all of this, I found Highlander to be better than expected.  I expected it to be awful, and was pleasantly surprised.  That's not to say it didn't have problems, but buried between them were some sparks of genius. Look at the musicians who try and imitate Eddie Vedder's voice (Creed).  This album is also still listened to by MANY people today, and how many albums from the 90's can you say that about?  Let's face it, besides Nirvana and Pearl Jam, there were only a handful of good artists to come out of the 90's era.  Anyway, this album is not the best you can find, but it does rank higher than the MTV music out now (can you tell i don't like MTV?).  I would recommend Nevermind before this, because I think it is a better rounded album.  Get this album used if you can.

B000059ZLH|5.0|There is little that needs to be written about Dream Theater's musical abilities; suffice it to say that this is probably their best live performance ever.  The camera work is fantastic - thank God Mike Portnoy directed, because he knows exactly who to show at what time.  When Jordan is doing some incredible keyboard work the camera is on him; when Petrucci is doing his usual insane soloing, he gets the spotlight...and there's some awesome usage of split screen views for when everyone is in the midst of a wild instrumental.  <br />Everyone has a fantastic show, and you can see how much they put into their playing...by the end of the second set, Portnoy is hitting himself on the head between riffs just to not pass out.  These guys are the finest musicians in rock/metal, hands down, and this DVD shows that they have a perfect balance of virtuosity and performing with emotion.  Particularly noteworthy is their performance of The Spirit Carries On, with full gospel choir and duet singing between Jamies LaBrie and Theresa Thompson.  Indescribably powerful and moving...during the audio commentary (which is also excellent - entertaining and interesting enough to re-watch the whole concert with it turned on) the band members agree that it was the pinnacle of their musical careers.<br />Some people have complained about the audio quality because it's not in 5.1 surround.  I enjoy surround sound as much as any audiophile, but I have no problem with a 2.0 stereo soundtrack if the audio is crisp.  The DVD sounds great on my system, and the mix is very good, so there's no reason to cut any stars because of it.  <br />The video quality is worthy of DVD.  I'm personally glad it's in 4:3 pan and scan.  Guess what, 99% of the viewing public doesn't have a wide screen TV and won't for the next few years.  I'd much rather have a full screen display, and I think most people with normal sized televisions will appreciate it too.<br />I also happened to like the video clips depicting thestory behind the concept album.  For the most part were only played full screen during transitions between songs, rarely did they cover up any important musical sections so they weren't intrusive.  The video work on these scenes isn't Hollywood professional, but actually has a gritty feel that fit really well in my opinion.<br />There's also a Ton of bonus footage on this DVD. I'm not giving anything away, but there are many secrets to be found, and well over three and a half hours of footage are captured.  <br />Thanks to Mike and the rest of Dream Theater for this fantastic DVD.  A band with their talent deserves to be captured for all to see.

B000002J1C|5.0|&quot;The Yes Album&quot; was actually the third album from the group spearheaded by singer John Anderson, but represented enough significant differences from its two predecessors to constitute a new and bigger beginning for the progressive rock group.  Guitarist Steve Howe had replaced Peter Banks (who had gone off to join Blodwyn Pig, remember?), the album featured only original material, and the songs now tended to be much longer tracks.  The four longer tracks--&quot;Yours Is No Disgrace,&quot; &quot;Starship Trooper,&quot; &quot;I've Seen All Good People,&quot; and &quot;Perpetual Change&quot;--are structured similarly, although each allows for considerable instrumental freedom.  Usually a melodic theme is introduced by one member of the band and then echoed by the others.  On this particular album the stand out musician is, rather surprisingly, bassist Chris Squire.  Sometimes I think they made a mistake on the mix and pumped up the volume on the bass, but then it becomes clear this is by design.  Howe's guitar work as well as the organ played by Tony Kaye are given their moments to shine while Bill Bruford's drumming just stays out of the way.  However, the defining element of Yes is probably the vocal harmonies, with Howe and Squire blending with Anderson in the falsetto range, highlighted on &quot;All Good People.&quot;  It was this that made Yes unique from their most obvious British progressive rock counterpart Emerson, Lake &amp; Palmer.  However, the best is yet to come, with the additional of Rick Wakeman as the keyboard player and Anderson's continued exploration of oblique lyrics.
B000001E18|5.0|ZOOROPA, more than any single U2 album, inspires not just loathing and disappointment, but boredom, a shrug of the shoulders.  Americans do not like this album, and this is perhaps the main reason I love this album so much, because it speaks a different musical language.<br />U2 spent the 80s searching for America, searching for the roots of their own sound.  The soundscapes were vast and epic and each album grew in grandeur as the band, seemingly, became a metaphor for the subject that it was analyzing artistically.<br />Come the 90s, following the diasaster of Rattle and Hum, and U2 turned away from America and towards Europe, a dense, confused, tower of Babel.  ZOOROPA is the perfect symbol for the Europe that emerged from the ruins of the Cold War.  It is a hodge-podge, a mish-mash, that twists and turns and lacks a thematic, ideological center.  For Americans this is confusing, but for Europeans, especially those like myself who heard the pastiche of radio signals that heralds the title track, this was a heightening of immediate reality, a statement on the world that we occupied.  I am selfish with this album because of that simple reason, because it is a European album, a exploration of chaos and the tenuous foundations upon which the new world order was to be constructed. <br />ZOOROPA is a statement on history.
0792151712|4.0|I wish people would stop crushing this movie for innane reasons. Ok, it's FINE if you don't like it--diversity of opinion is what makes the world go 'round! But it would be highly desirable to know what you're talking about before you make a fool of yourself. For instance, one reviewer said that the movie would have been better if the Titanic actually reached NY. Well, it would have been DIFFERENT, except that the really Titanic sank more or less exactly as depicted in the film. Cameron made some gnarly mistakes with the script, but he wasn't stupid (or brilliant) enough to change history for his little blockbuster.   Another reviewer commented that what happened in the movie wasn't possible. Cameron's characters are all strong, if somewhat cliched, but everything they did was possible. Love is LOVE, no matter where you throw it in what era. Of course, social opinion has differed over the ages, and it always affects people, but if no one before now ever thought to go against public opinion, or choose happiness over wealth, we'd be nowhere. There is such a thing as human feeling... and doesn't the film make it perfectly obvious why Jack went to dinner with Rose? He'd saved her life! And anyway, nobody but Rose approved--at least, nobody but those people who were actually fooled into thinking Jack was first class, and those (like Andrews and Kathy Bates) who were too down-to-earth and reasonable to whine about Rose's dinner guest. And it's quite obvious that both Ruth and Cal went out of their way to embarrass Jack.    I suppose what I mean is that, while this movie has its faults (and some of them are pretty big) it's JUST a movie--a few people's idea of a good love story. It was historically accurated, entertaining, emotionally elavating and stimulating, etc. I agree that DiCaprio wasn't the best choice for Jack by far, but Winslet was incredible enough to make up for it, and anyway, he pulled it off OK.   So relax and don't bother to waste time bashing movies you may not have enjoyed. Find a movie you DID like, and review it.

B000002J1F|5.0|\\"Fragile\\" is the Yes album that has the progressive rock group's best known track \\"Roundabout,\\" but I would certainly side with those who count \\"Close to the Edge\\" as their best album (and the Billboard ratings support the idea since \\"Close to the Edge\\" made it to #3 and \\"Fragile\\" only to #4).  The big difference between this album released in December 1971 was that Rick Wakeman replaced Tony Kaye on keyboards.  While I have also preferred Keith Emerson as a keyboard artist you can certainly admire how Wakeman's flamboyant artistry is integrated into the Yes sound.<br /><br />What keeps this from being the group's best album are the little signs of pretentiousness with \\"Cans and Brahms\\" and \\"We Have Heaven.\\" Lose those tracks and \\"Fragile\\" is a pretty good ride from start to finish. The opening of \\"Roundabout\\" (which always sounds like the beginning of ELP's \\"In the Beginning\\"--is there an in-joke here I am missing?) features Steve Howe's nimble-fingered guitar playing before the rest of the band joins in on the fun that builds to a crescendo until all that is left is Wakeman's organ-simulated lake of water and Jon Anderson's pure voice. Chris Squire's bass and Bill Bruford's drumming stand out on \\"South Side Of The Sky,\\" but \\"Heart of the Sunrise\\" is the album's monster track and the best example overall of the group's progressive rock style. Anderson's lyrics are cryptic at best, but listening to Yes was always about the evocative sounds not the meaning of the words.<br /><br />I read that \\"Fragile\\" was completed in less than two months because the group needed to help pay for all of Wakeman's equipment.  Because it was put together quickly there are really just four tracks featuring the entire group and five shorter pieces showcasing the individual band members.  So you have Anderson's overdubbed voice on \\"We Have Heaven,\\" Squire's playing lead bass on \\"The Fish,\\"  Bruford's drums on \\"Five Percent for Nothing,\\" Howe's playing classical guitar on \\"Mood for a Day,\\" and Wakeman's \\"Cans and Brhams,\\" where he takes a movement from Brahams's Fourth Symphony and creates a electronic keyboard fantasy.  The album was given a boost by an edited version of \\"Roundabout\\" that was released as a single and climbed to #13 on the Billboard chart.  Yes would not do better until 1983 with \\"Owner of a Lonely Heart,\\" which only emphasizes that the group's best tracks were not suited for AM Top Forty airplay.  Yes was an FM group perfectly content to devote an entire album side to one song, as they amply proved on \\"Close to an Edge.\\"\\"Cans and Brhams,\\" where he takes a movement from Brahams's Fourth Symphony and creates a electronic keyboard fantasy. Yes was an FM group perfectly content to devote an entire album side to one song, as they amply proved on \\"Close to an Edge.\\"

0812548094|1.0|Good writing consists of just a few basic things: interesting dialogue, concise sentences/paragraphs, and focused ideas/plot/characters. Sadly, none of Goodkind's works contain these three simple writing rules.<br />Interesting dialogue: &quot;You are a *special* person, Richard.&quot; &quot;You're my friend... That's what friends are for...&quot; This is really annoying when it comes up nearly every other page. Goodkind simplifies his dialogue to the point where an attentive reader will feel insulted. Come on, chum, we're not that retarded (unless you've been buying the whole damn series).<br />Concise sentences/paragraphs: Why in the hell is this book 1000 pages long? Even &quot;War and Peace&quot; isn't this long, and it's got enough epic plot to fill a hundred Goodkind novels. This boy needs an editor to distill this crap down. Longer does not equal better. (Read the Earthsea novels.)<br />Focused ideas/plot/characters: It's like wandering in Wonderland, but lacking Alice's cat. There are a quite a few focused ideas here: sexual perversion, gratuitous violence, defecation (read the part about the palace), cardboard relationships, cliches, etc. Unfocused include: truth, magic, characters, and plot. The magic system is unwieldy, insipid, and simplistic (additive and negative magics?!). Goodkind mentioned something about &quot;righteous anger&quot; in the first novel; good to see that &quot;righteous anger&quot; actually means &quot;righteous slaughter/murder.&quot; He should've told us earlier. Richard and Kahlan are like love-sick teenagers, and the combined IQ of these two is lower than my caesar salad. Actually, one should ask: What plot? If there is a meaningful plot here, I'll be amazed.<br />One could write an English doctoral thesis on Goodkind's usage, but his list of follies also includes all the &quot;borrowed&quot; ideas from Robert Jordan (who suffers many of the same problems) and Terry Brooks (ditto). We're going to keep on receiving crap in fantasyand science fiction until we demand better authors. At this point, it doesn't seem likely though...
B0000025F7|5.0|When Michael Jackson released Off The Wall in 1979, he was a mere 21 years old, but he had been in the business for a decade.  He had released several solo albums and singles (even topping the charts with &quot;Ben&quot; in 1972), but they were under the control of Motown. Off The Wall was his first real solo release as he was in charge.  Mr. Jackson was always thought of as an unique talent, but he blew away everyone's expectations with the album.  The album has a definite dance vibe, but although disco was at its height of popularity, the album doesn't fall in the disco category.  The songs have fat grooves that make you want to dance, but the core of the songs belong to Mr. Jackson and not the production as is the case with most disco songs.  &quot;Don't Stop 'Til You Get Enough&quot; is the album's first track and single.  It is a brilliant track with soaring strings and popping rhythms that has a spoken word intro that moves into a high falsetto.  Mr. Jackson sings the song in the falsetto, but he interjects spoken word into verses that provide an echo to the lead.  The song was a justifiable number one hit.  &quot;Rock With You&quot; was the second single and is much slower in its beat, but you can still groove to it.  It also topped the charts.  &quot;Working Day &amp; Night&quot; is a musical workout that sounds like a forerunner of &quot;Wanna Be Startin' Something&quot; from Thriller.  &quot;Get On The Floor&quot; is a fiery call to arms that in which he doesn't ask that you get up and dance, but demands it.  The title track has a funky vibe to it and &quot;Girlfriend&quot; is a Paul McCartney song that is pumped up a bit from its slight original, but is still the weakest track on the album.  &quot;She's Out Of My Life&quot; is a straight ballad that is sung with heartbreaking sincerity.  In fact Mr. Jackson literally broke down while singing it and you can hear the sobbing on the song.  &quot;Burn The Disco Out&quot; closes the album in apocalyptic fashion and is a perfect capper to the album.  Off The Wall was a major success that spawned four top ten hits, sold over 10 million copies but surprising never hit number one on the album charts, topping out at number three.  Although Thriller became a cultural phenomenon and the biggest selling album in music history for a time, many people consider Off The Wall his true masterpiece.n and is a perfect capper to the album. 078401115X|5.0|is fully evident in this late 80s Alan Parker film, an overlooked classic if there ever was one.  In my opinion, no one then or now could do the job portraying detective Harry Angel that Rourke did.  He captures every nuance of the character perfectly, running the gamut from emotional wreckage to physical haggardness.  How someone so gifted could let said gift get away from him the way Rourke did is a mystery almost as compelling as the one serving as the subject of this film.<br />The basic storyline is deceptively simple; Harry Angel is a down and out post WWII New York detective hired by a shadowy figure to find a missing singer, one Johnny Favorite.  That search leads him from New York City to the bowels of the Louisiana bayou, and it's that setting that gives the film so much of its powerful atmosphere.  Things are not as they seem, and the story becomes stranger the further along it goes...  <br />Alan Parker did a fantastic job of using muted colors to convey the sense that this story is not taking place in our time, but rather one of a recently faded past.  Visually, the film transports you to that place and moment in a way that few &quot;period pieces&quot; manage to accomplish.  Add in his notorious attention to detail, and you have little doubt that you are seeing the deep south of Louisiana as it was in the 1950s.<br />The other major performances (Robert De Niro, Charlotte Rampling, Lisa Bonet, Brownie McGhee) are wonderful in their own right, but IMO, this is Rourke's show.  A modern classic!

Dangerous is an eclectic mixed bag that Mr. Jackson shows he is willing to mix it up and try different things.

The lyrical meaning revolves around mankind's demise at his own hands, via nuclear war. The title track is a heavy song that deals with unfair treatment of inmates, namely, the electric chair. &quot;For Whom the Bell Tolls&quot; is a very epic song about dying needlessly in war, similar to &quot;Disposable Heroes&quot; on Master of Puppets. &quot;Fade to Black&quot; is a slower song, which is based on being intensely depressed, to the point of suicide. The somber,melancholic tone definitely reflects the meaning. &quot;Escape&quot; is a weaker song, easily the lowlight on this particular disc. But then, it's better than most bands' best. &quot;Trapped Under Ice&quot; is probably about censorship, but the lyrics are somewhat vague. Then comes my favorite, &quot;Creeping Death&quot;. It is drawn from Exodus, in the Old Testament. It is based on the final plague of Egypt, the Angel of Death. Finally, the end track, &quot;Call of Ktulu&quot;, a reference to a horror story by H.P. Lovecraft. If you come across anything by that author, read it to this. Overall, this is an excellent album, worth every cent. Fans of new bands, as I was, check out any of Metallica's older discs. If you are already an old-school metalhead, you should have owned this since it came out. Just buy it !!
B000001GPX|5.0|When it comes to buying one of Beethoven symphonies on disc usually you have to choices: to go with the classics (Furtwangler, Klemperer, Walter) and their powerfull and insightfull approaches or to get a more modern approach (to Hogwood) sometimies with pretty strange results. To find a recording that stands somewhere between, that is both emotionally powerfull and yet full of energy of our time the choice isn't easy. And that's where Kleiber comes in. With an extremely responsive orchestra and impecable recorded sound Kleiber gets the perfect balance between classic and modern interpretation. All the tension we were used by conductors like Furtwangler and all the grisp of someone like Karajan is there in a perfect combination of something that must be one of the landmarks in recorded Beethoven and in recorded music of all times. Buy this CD and listen to it. It's as rewarding as people here say. Definitely an essential recording.

The story is told from the perspective of young Francis Mccourt, from the young age of 5 until he hits the age of 19, and we see him mature before our own eyes as the writing manner changes from chapter to chapter. This is a story of how Francis McCourt lived and survived through the desolation of his childhood, with a drunken father. The start of the book is very depressing, with the death of Frank's baby sister, following deaths of his twin brothers, many parts of the books still have funny descriptions. I found myself laughing along the way reading this book and defiantly putting a smile on my face. It is truly amazing the kid has not gone into depression in such an inconsiderate atmosphere. He even had dreams of going to America and earning big bucks, which many had tried to convince him to forget. Frank is one determined person to succeed. This is a book not to miss, the insight of Frank is truly amazing and you see life through a totally different light!

B000002U82|5.0|Pink Floyd has made some of the most powerful music in rock history, but none of their albums manage to reach the importance and grandeur of 1973's Dark Side of the Moon.   Since their formation in 1966, the band's compositions progressively pointed to the conceptual perfection found in this amazing song cycle.  <br />Even as early as 1968, with &quot;A Saucerful of Secrets,&quot; the group was forming multi-sectioned song ideas.  A single from the same year, &quot;Careful With That Axe Eugene,&quot; with its quiet start and explosive ending,  contained an evolution of emotion that was very important to the developing Pink Floyd sound.  Movie soundtracks such as More (1969) and Obscured by Clouds (1972) fed Roger Water's desire to make albums that were much more than a collection of British pop songs.   Atom Heart Mother in 1970 showed even more growth from the band.  \\"Alan's Psychedelic Breakfast\\" experimented with sound effects.  The &quot;Atom Heart Mother&quot; suite, which covered an entire album side, was their first attempt at a lengthy piece.  This was improved upon in &quot;Echoes&quot; from Meddle (1971).  All this led to the creation of a piece of music that would stand on its own as a full listening experience.<br />The concept is simple, yet deep at the same time.  Things that drive mankind mad: wealth, conserving/wasting time, and failed interaction with others.  There are tape recorded interviews that pop up from time to time creating a very erie feel.  And the engineering of the recording is flawless.<br />Dark Side of the Moon has a fluid, cohesive feel to it that is never interrupted throughout its 42 minutes.  From beginning to end, there are no low points. Challengers to this will point to moments that are fully justified by the context of the album.  For example, the drum intro to &quot;Time&quot; might be looked upon as too long, but when the listener realizes what the song is about, it fits in like a glove.  The female, non-lyrical vocal in &quot;Any Color You Like&quot; may seem tedious at first listen, but then it sets the perfect tone for the pause before &quot;Money.&quot;  Which brings up an interesting point.  The break point between albums sides could not have occurred at a better spot.  While listening to the CD version of the album, this pause has a very dramatic effect.  It's as if Waters had the digital age in mind.  The beginning of the album is effective as well.  It starts  with a heartbeat, followed by a collage of sounds from later songs, and then &quot;Breathe in the Air,&quot; a perfect opener.   The same can be said for the end of the record, the  Roger Waters composition &quot;Eclipse.&quot;  Waters has been notorious for his songs with lists as lyrics, but this one works perfectly. It feels like something great is coming to a close, and indeed it is.  <br />There would be other great Pink Floyd Albums, most notably Wish You Were Here, Animals, and The Wall.  They are some of the great achievements of rock, but Dark Side of the Moon is perfect.
B000000WCA|5.0|This is one of my favorite pop music CDs ever. For some weird reason Europeans write better pop music than America. 0446310786|4.0|The book To Kill A Mockingbird captures serious issues that are  occurring in society through the eyes of a naive elementary school girl.  The symbols and underlying themes are  told through the innocence of the young child, Scout.  This brings an interesting point of view  to the story because she does not understand the stereotypes that exist in her  small town.  She also doesn't  realize that complications that her dad, a lawyer faces.  Social standings and relationships  between family, friends, and neighbors are explored in this story. The book starts at the end of the story, and there is a flashback through  all of Scout's adventures.  This  book is an exciting collection of events in Scout 's life that together reflect  on society as a whole.  This social  commentary by Harper Lee, shows how a young girl who hasn 't been subjected to  the prejudicial views of society is able to judge character better than  wise  adults that have been through many experiences.  To Kill A Mockingbird is fun summer reading, that leaves the reader with something to think  about.

B000002NHN|5.0|I feel that Loreena McKennitt is one of the most important composers of our time.  She writes musical pieces that I believe the world will treasure forever.<br />She uses her well-ranged, but generally soprano voice in a semi-operatic fashion.  Sometimes, she borrows poems from other places and times, and sets them to music.  Other times, she writes her own words.  But the rich, multi-layered, almost orchestraic music she composes in the background is what really makes her albums brilliant.  Not that her voice by itself isn't lovely.<br />This is classy music for rich-hearted music lovers.  If you only buy one Loreena McKennitt album, I think The Book of Secrets is the one.  But you'd be crazy to buy only one.  Buy the rest of them too!  And keep them in fancy jeweled cases, showcased prominently in your living room.  Because you will soon consider each of them to be a treasure.

B00000IMTE|4.0|Rainbow was formed in 1975 by lead guitar legend Ritchie Blackmore immediately after leaving Deep Purple.  He met and struck up a friendship with Ronnie James Dio, who was fronting the bluesy hard rock band Elf.  Ritchie was so impressed with Ronnie and the band that he formed Rainbow out of Elf.  In other words, when they first began, Rainbow was basically Elf (minus their own lead guitarist, of course) plus Ritchie Blackmore.<br />Although Elf was basically a bar-room boogie band, both Ritchie and Ronnie envisioned Rainbow to be more of a progressive metal outfit with lyrics concentrating on mystical, medieval, and occult themes.  This is why Rainbow's first record has both of these styles represented on it.<br />It begins with what might be the greatest Rainbow song ever (certainly one of their greatest anyway, as well as one of THE best songs from 1975), a 4 1/2-minute song called &quot;Man On The Silver Mountain.&quot;  This is the original song that defined Rainbow's music:  it starts with a good basic electric guitar riff, then the bass, drums and keyboards join in for support, and when Ronnie James Dio starts to sing, it quickly begins to take shape as the progressive heavy metal song it is.  And it has one amazing guitar solo by Ritchie Blackmore!<br />&quot;Self Portrait&quot; is also a dynamic prog-metal tune, but &quot;Black Sheep Of The Family&quot; is a straight-ahead, slightly bluesy hard rock tune with some great slide guitar work by Blackmore, and is obviously one of the Elf-penned contributions to this record.  It is also quite infectious; once you hear it, you can't get it out of your mind for hours.<br />&quot;Catch The Rainbow,&quot; at six and a half minutes long, is the only long song on this album, and is also the most progressive-sounding.  It's the one that really paved the way for their next album &quot;Rising,&quot; as it sounds more similar to the songs on that record than anything on this one.  It's a nice, introspective tune.  &quot;Snake Charmer&quot; is almost the opposite; it is a short, loud, brash song that contains a lot of Dio-screaming on it. &quot;The Temple Of The King&quot; gets Rainbow back into fine progressive form, with lyrics conjuring up the medieval.  The, they do a sudden roots-rock-about-face with the VERY Elf-sounding, piano-and-bass-driven, ultra-infectious &quot;If You Don't Like Rock 'N' Roll,&quot; which some reviewers have dismissed on here, but I think it provides a neat departure for Rainbow on this album.  Besides, it shows all of us where Ronnie James Dio really came from (no, not Hell):  He came from rock's early days. That's right, he formed his very first band all the way back in 1958, called Ronnie and The Rumblers, so you can tell that he still had some of that influence left in him by the time this album was made.  I think it's pretty cool. :)<br />The CD winds down with &quot;Sixteenth-Century Greensleeves&quot; and &quot;Still I'm Sad.&quot;  The former is probably the most medieval-sounding track on here, about a revolt against a tyrant, with some evil-sounding singing by Dio.  The latter is simply one of the greatest heavy metal instumentals ever, with fast time-changes on bass and drums, and absolutely amazing guitar fretwork by The Man In Black.<br />If you know only a couple of their later hit songs, then give early Rainbow a try, especially if you already like Deep Purple.  Some of these songs are very Deep Purple-ish.  If you also like Ronnie James Dio's 80's stuff, then this CD is for you!  And...If you don't like rock 'n' roll, THEN YOU'RE TOO LATE NOW! :)
630528069X|4.0|N.Y.C.Detective John McClane (Bruce Willis) arrives in Los Angeles.Its Christmas,so people expect good will,and presents from each other.But in a place high enough to see all of L.A.,McClane only wants to see his wife.The International gate-crashing terrorists who are not in party mood, want to take full control of the building,speak to Mr Takagi,and steal $640,000,000 of bonds in a high tech vault.The Leader of the terrorists is Hans Gruber,a well dressed,well spoken recipient of a classical education.Hans wants the cash,but expects local law enforcement to not co-operate.But Hans did not expect local to be on the next level.Die Hard is without a doubt a non-stop display of thrilling action scenes,and a good performance by Bruce Willis as McClane.Alexander Godunov as Gruber's evil sidekick is excellent,displaying a touch of the psychotic.However,Alan Rickman gives a flawless performance as Hans Gruber,a ruthless,determined,more refined type of terrorist,a performance that literally commands attention,and probably what has become the first thing many people remember,when &quot;Die Hard&quot; 0804106304|5.0|The Joy Luck Club By Amy Tan<br /> The Joy Luck Club by Amy Tan is no doubt, one of the most enchanting American-Chinese books I have ever read. It was written based on some of the old Chinese history and traditions, traveling through a time line from the early 1900s to the 1990s. It tells the story of four mothers and their daughters. Each story describes the lives of the mothers and how their histories made impacts on their daughters. Every one of them is different, some are heart wrenching, bringing me to the verge of tears, some of them are more optimistic, and definitely inspirational.  Amy Tan clearly portrayed differences in the mothers and their daughters in their opinions and perceptions of the things, drawing a well-defined line between the old traditional Chinese beliefs and the modern first generation American concepts. Yet, amidst these differences, little similarities were slowly revealed. She made use of certain events to draw the parallels in the mother-daughter relationships, and little symbolic metaphors that sum up each story. Little things that hide behind the big events slowly uncover themselves each time I read this book. Although this is an American Chinese book, it would definitely still be interesting for other races to find out more about the Chinese culture and to understand its traditions better. This is indeed Asian-American literature at its best and I would not hesitate to recommend this book to anyone.<br />-

B00004YYDI|5.0|Wow, is all I can really say, words can't really describe the greatness of this movie. A friend of mine lent me the DVD, I was busy at the time so it sat on my rack for a week or so. One evening when I was bored I decided to watch a few movies. Seven, being the first movie I watched was great. Still in the movie mood, being a little skeptical at first I decided to try The Professional. When the movie played and the title 'Leon' appeared I thought I might of had to the wrong movie, but it turns out this was the title for the movie everywhere but in the US, so I continued watching. I won't completely give this movie away if you're reading this and haven't watched it yet, I'll just write about what you can basically see in the trailer.<br />Jean Reno plays Leon, a 'cleaner' who is truly a professional at what he does, killing people. But the one who really steals the show has to be Natalie Portman. Being only 12 years old, her acting in this movie is truly amazing. She makes it look so natural, especially the scenes in the movie that are very emotional. I can't imagine anyone that could play the role of Mathilda any better then she did. .... The musical score in this movie is definately one of a kind. Eric Serra is able to put the perfect (yes, perfect) music together with the scenes, making the emotional scenes have a much larger impact on the viewers. Listening to the soundtrack is amazing because the movie plays back in your mind as you're listening to the music having the same emotional impact as if you were watching the movie. Last but certainally not least is the director, Luc Besson. I've never even heard of Luc Besson (he directed the Fifth Element which I have seen but didn't know he directed it) until I saw this movie. Words can't even describe how he did on this movie. His style of will certainally be admired for along time. The camera work (he's his own camera man) in this movie, is, for lack of a better word, amazing. This is definately one of the best movies I've ever seen (and I've seen many movies), this film will remembered for along time. What troubles me though is the fact that the US version of the film had 24-minutes of the footage edited out. After reading what scenes were taken out, I couldn't believe it. The scenes that were taken out add depth and add to the impact of the movie. B00000637V|5.0|two things undermine 'berlin', the first being the fact that it's unrelentingly depressing; to be appreciated fully one has to be hitting an all-time low, it is then that listening to this makes complete sense and is truly rewarding; the other thing is the music, especially in the first part, the bombastic arrangements work against it; 'berlin' works best in the second half, particularly songs like 'caroline says II' and 'the kids', which are sparsely arranged and cut to te bone, but 'sad song' on the other hand is simply swapmed by all the instruments somethering it, the same goes for 'lady day' and 'caroline says I'; ultimately it's unfortunate as the songs are hauntingly beautiful, the second caroline being among the saddest songs ever recorded and 'the kids' certainly one of the most disconcerting; reed is chillingly resigned in his singing, the crucial line being 'me, i just don' care at all'; it would translate into next year's 'sally can't dance' album when the resignation turned into outright hate, the key line on that album being 'isn't it nice/when your heart is made out of ice'; so, perhaps it's no wonder that this bombed when it came out in 1973, it's just too much of a bummer to be enyjoed and listened to frequently, although it is a genuinely impressive collection of songs; highlights: 'caroline says II', 'the kids', 'oh jim'

031286504X|5.0|I am astonished at the fact that this novel recieved any bad reviews.  I can understand the fact that some readers felt cheated by the fact that the book included short stories after the novel, but this was simply an added bonus for any Matheson fans.  Enough about other ratings, now I'll explain why I feel the book deserves five stars.<br />The idea of the book alone is enough to make you try reading it.  A plague has turned the Earth's humans into vampires, and there is only one man left.<br />After hearing this idea some readers may be thinking that it sounds silly, or has been done before, but belive me; nothing like this has ever been done before.  For many vampire novels, the author simply gives the vampires the traditional powers and weaknesses, (crosses, garlic, etc.) but Richard Matheson goes so far as to explain why all this is true.  The explanations he gives, though they may seem far-fetched, are extremely plausible when Matheson describes them.  It seems as if Matheson did a lot of scientific research for this novel, because his explanations of DNA are terrific.<br />Finally, don't read this novel if you're just looking for a normal horror novel.  Read it if you're looking for an intelligent, suspenseful tale of a world overtaken by vampires.
0930289234|5.0|The title of my review is presumptuous and probably unwarrented, but I feel that every person on earth should read this book and then... then all the false, callow, poor authors who look down at illustrated writing can go hang themselves in shame.<br />The Watchmen is a Novel in 12 parts. It is a mystery, a story within a story and so many more things than I can say... From the murder of a murderer to the zen realization that their are no happy endings because nothing ends...<br />If you find the idea even mildly intriguing, buy this book... now... today... read and re-read it till the pages fall apart. Graciously give it to everyone you know... and the tell them to buy a copy and do the same.<br />That's what books are for afterall.

0790731983|5.0|CABARET has never looked better, remastered for it's 25th anniversary, with additional features.<br />Liza Minnelli gives the performance of her career as the singer Sally Bowles, on a self-imposed exile in Berlin, entertaining at the seedy Kit Kat Klub.<br />Into her life comes Brian Roberts (Michael York), a mild-mannered English bisexual who falls in love with her.  Both are seduced by the wealthy Maximillian (Helmut Griem) before Sally falls pregnant, aborts the child and Brian leaves Berlin just as the Nazi's gain power.<br />The musical, set against the stormy backdrop of Berlin in the 1930's, is a marvellous piece of film making.  Directed and choreographed by maestro Bob Fosse, CABARET also boasts original Broadway performer Joel Grey as the Master of Ceremonies, and Fritz Wepper and Marisa Berenson.<br />Also includes reminiscences by Liza Minnelli, Joel Grey, Michael York, Cy Feuer, John Kander and others from the creative team, an old featurette on the making of the film, and the original theatrical trailer.

B000002LGA|5.0|I had heard \\"Walk On the Wild Side\\" with my father as a child, and although there were lyrics there at the time I didn't fully understand, the song made a significant impact.  I saw \\"New York\\" in a record (there were still a few) store when it was released and decided to buy it (I was 12).  This album touched me then, as it does now.  In different ways, to be sure.  I have matured and can understand more fully the depth of this music I could only bearly appreciate as a younger boy.  Where has this kind of heart-felt, lyric rich, desperate yet hopeful music gone?  Very few musicians, or people in general, obtain a mastery of language as Lou Reed has.  His ability to convey thought and emotion while both telling a story and making a commentary on the Human Condition is awe inspiring and motivating.  When I have lost hope in Humankind I put on Lou Reed.  I would give my right arm to make art like this.  This is what redeems us all.
